IUCN Red List of Threatened Species

The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species is a global initiative assessing the extinction risk of various organisms, including fish.

Each species is categorized based on the following criteria

1. Data Deficient (DD) Insufficient data to make an assessment of extinction risk.
2. Least Concern (LC) Species at low risk of extinction.
3. Near Threatened (NT) Species that may become threatened in the near future.
4. Vulnerable (VU) Species likely to become endangered unless conditions improve.
5. Endangered (EN) Species at a very high risk of extinction.
6. Critically Endangered (CR) Species at an extremely high risk of extinction.
7. Extinct in the Wild (EW) Species surviving only in captivity or outside their native range.
8. Extinct (EX) Species no longer in existence.
9. Not Evaluated (NE) Has not yet been evaluated against the criteria.
Harvesting fish at their ideal size promotes sustainability and population stability.
It is the biggest size recorded. Knowing a fish\'s maximum size is vital for conservation, preventing overfishing, and sustainable management.
We value your feedback! If you have any comments, suggestions, or concerns, please feel free to share them with us via email. Your input helps us improve our services.
